metadata.title: Become a Quantum Computing Programmer | by Amelie Schreiber | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Quantum computing is seen by many as a technology of the future. In this article, we’re going to look at how to run some non-trivial programs on actual quantum computers. In particular, we’re going…

all_paragraphs: Quantum computing is seen by many as a technology of the future. In this article, we’re going to look at how to run some non-trivial programs on actual quantum computers. In particular, we’re going to discuss something called graph states. Graph states are used for quantum cryptography, quantum error correction, and measurement based quantum computing. If all of that sounds like a foreign language, that’s okay. We’re going to go through everything, from the ground up, and in detail…and don’t worry, we’ll keep it light and fun.

What is quantum computing? Quantum computing should be thought of as an ASIC, or “Application Specific Integrated Circuit” such as a GPU used to accelerate machine learning. They shouldn’t be thought of as a replacement for standard “classical” computers like your laptop, smartphone, or one of the supercomputers used by companies like Google to process mass amounts of data and train machine learning models for several days. Quantum computers are a specialized computational resource that we send certain problems to. Quantum computers process information in a fundamentally different way from the standard binary processes in a standard computer. They use properties like “interference”, “superposition”, and “entanglement” to gain an advantage over classical computers in solving certain kinds of problems. While a universal quantum computer can do anything a classical computer can do, the problem we are interested in solving determines whether we want to use a quantum computer.

The most popular model of quantum computing is the circuit model, which described operations on qubits as a sequence of gates which can be represented as a matrix being multiplied by a vector. Let’s look at an example.

First, you’ll need to download the free Jupyter notebook tool which comes in the latest (also free) distribution of Anaconda. Once you’ve downloaded this, open the Anaconda navigator, and open an instance of “Jupyter Lab”. It will give you the option to run a Python 3 kernel, select it. Next, you’ll see a window with cells, which you can change to dark mode if you’re into the hacker aesthetic.
Now, in the first cell, run the following commands to import the libraries you’ll need.
Once you’ve done this, create a “Quantum Register” and a “Classical Register” as follows, along with a “Quantum Circuit”.

The quantum and classical registers should be thought of as channels of information for bits and qubits. In this circuit we have two qubits and two classical bits. Now, let’s perform some operations on our qubits! Let’s prepare a “Bell state”. The Bell states are classical examples that exhibit entanglement. They are sometimes called EPR-states due to the commentary from Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen in a classic paper on how these quantum states exhibit entanglement. The following code will build a circuit that applies a “Hadamard gate” to the first qubit, and a “CNOT” gate to the first and second qubit, and then draws the circuit.
The above circuit can be interpreted in terms of linear algebra as follows:
If you’re not an expert at linear algebra, that’s okay, Python and NumPy can do this computation for us…
This outputs the state vector that results from running the quantum circuit we constructed.

Now, the state vector that we have just constructed exhibits entanglement as well as superposition. It exists in a combination of two state at once, unlike classical bits which are always zeros and ones. In particular, our state vector represents the combination of the two states “00” and “11”. So, either both qubits are either spin-up or spin-down when measured, but the outcome is probabilistic and will be one 50% of the time, and the other 50% of the time. The fascinating thing is, we only need to measure one qubit to know what state the other qubit is in! This is due to the entanglement. We don’t need to observe the second qubit to know that it is in whatever state the first qubit is in. If we want to run this on one of IBMs quantum computers, we can construct this circuit in the (free) IBM Quantum Experience, using an interactive drag and drop circuit composer. Sign up for an account, then navigate over to the circuit composer in the side bar.
Now, click on the “New Circuit” button.

Next, simply drag and drop the following circuits onto the circuit diagram. This will prepare the same Bell state as what we prepared, and will measure the first qubit (the little black meter symbol with a z).
You can get a visualization on the left side of the two states you are likely to measure if you run this circuit.
You can run this on an IBM quantum computer in the cloud, and get your results back depending on how long the wait list (number of jobs on that hardware) is. It’s as simple as that!
Now, if you’d like to construct a graph state, you can use the following function we wrote using NetworkX over at The Singularity Research.
You’ll need to run the following imports:
And this function will define a graph state quantum circuit:
If we define the following graph in NetworkX:
We can feed “G” into the “graph_state_measure(G)” function and get the following circuit:

Circuits like this are called graph states because the exhibit entanglement based on the graph we define them by. The pink “CZ-gates” that connect two lines in the circuit diagram correspond to edges in the graph, and the nodes of the graph correspond to the qubits running along the black lines of the circuit diagram. These graph states can be used in quantum cryptography (see this interactive notebook). They are also used in error correction (see this interactive notebook).

If you’d like to know more about quantum computing and if you’d like to work through more advanced tutorials addressing things like entanglement, entropy, and complicated circuits and algorithms, you can check out The Singularity’s Github page. We have tons of interactive notebooks you can run in your browser without having to download anything! You can also check out IBM’s excellent online book for Qiskit, which covers some similar topics in a slightly different way, as well as some different topics. Feel free to get in touch and ask a question to thesingularity.research@gmail.com. Be sure to include “Hacking the Universe” in your subject line so the email isn’t missed. We can help you get started with using quantum technologies, and quantum machine learning.
